title: Essequibo: Venezuela sends troops to border, Guyana says it has 'no plan' for attack - Teller Report
text: Essequibo: Venezuela sends troops to border, Guyana says it has 'no plan' for attack In the midst of the crisis over Essequibo, an oil-rich territory claimed by Venezuela, some 5,600 Venezuelan troops are taking part in military exercises of a "defensive" nature ordered Thursday by President Nicolas Maduro in "response to the provocation and threat of the United Kingdom," which has sent a warship to Guyana. Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro meets with staff at the Ministry of Defense in Caracas, Dec. 28, 2023. © Jhonn Zerpa/Miraflores Palace/Handout via REUTERS By: RFI Follow Advertising Read More As the two Latin American countries vie over the Essequibo region, interference from the United Kingdom, of which Guyana has long been a colony, is seen as a provocation to Venezuela. On Sunday 24 December, London announced the deployment of a military patrol ship, HMS Trent. In response, Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro announced on Thursday, December 28, a "defensive" military action by Venezuela in the face of the "threat" of a British ship in Guyana. In total, more than 5,600 Venezuelan soldiers have been taking part in military manoeuvres of a "defensive" nature since Thursday, December 28. "I have ordered the activation of a joint action of all the [Venezuelan] Bolivarian National Armed Forces in the Eastern Caribbean, on the Atlantic coast, a joint action of a defensive nature, in response to the provocation and threat of the United Kingdom against the peace and sovereignty of our country," President Maduro said during a radio and television broadcast. in which he showed images of warships and fighter jets patrolling the area. Read alsoEssequibo: "the effects of the announcement have not been followed by effects" Tensions have been exacerbated for several months For his part, Guyana's Vice President, Bharrat Jagdeo, is trying to ease tensions with his words. "We have no plan to take offensive measures against Venezuela... We have no intention of invading Venezuela. President Maduro knows this and should not be worried," he told a news conference. He also said the arrival of a British patrol boat in Guyana's waters was part of "routine exercises that have been planned for a long time". This territorial dispute, which has existed since 1899, has returned to the forefront of the news with the launch, last September, of oil tenders by Guyana, followed by the referendum held on 3 December in Venezuela on a proposal to annex Essequibo. This 160,000 km2 territory, rich in oil and natural resources, administered by Georgetown but claimed by Venezuela, covers two-thirds of Guyana's land area. It is home to about 125,000 people, or one-fifth of the country's population. Read alsoVenezuela-Guyana: could the crisis degenerate into conflict?
